Growing up in ad-hoc trans groups that never formed in anything except apropos chat groups, which some on this board might describe as dens of HSTS-dom, though I don't believe in such a rigid dichotomy, I particularly found myself being called things by various friends such as "nice," "quiet," and "likely to be abused." Furthermore, I have expressed in these groups and elsewhere my distaste for lecherous behavior, in addition to aggressive behavior and more or less anything that seems toxically male. In this I have held primarily that there is a direct connection one may feel with others who share the same connection as you. In the exact same way if you were extremely depressed, and met someone who also was, you could immediately say a few words and know you both knew the same experience, so too with the dysphoria thing.
Because of this, on my surface at least to my awareness I appear to be a particularly nice, particularly harmless, trutrans boymoder or something of sorts.
At times I have even discussed how, when I was 12, looking for scientific methods in biology and chemistry, and magical methods in the occult, I would occasionally come across proto-trans, sissy, crossdress, and other such websites and find myself disgusted and appalled. I at length have described my feelings as a child/adolescent of simply feeling an inexorable need to be a girl (read, female), and how these depictions originally first struck me as further from becoming female than simply being a regular man. When I first saw the trans rights thing saying "you are a woman because you identify as one" I thought this was a group of people who had learned what I was (a normal boy who wants to be a normal girl) and were making fun of me and people like me.
I have never once girlmoded outside/in public except for in a schoolgirl outfit once on halloween when I was 18/19. Otherwise though I was a trap online and originally identified as one from about 17-20 or so.

I learned what trans was at about 14 or 15, and didn't accept I was trans until I was 16, and when I tepidly, half-heartedly first did, I cried a shit ton and hated it.
I remember first distinctively having strong feelings of which I could actively remember occurring day to day in consistence and without stop as the single highest wish I could have for myself, enough so that I could articulate it in my head at every opportunity from the ages of 12 on. And I have other memories suggesting such feelings in a prototypal form from at least as early as 9 on.
At 17 I came out to my mom as trans, I originally did this by saying I needed to tell her something, then not being able to for like an hour, before she tearily asked if I was gay, to which I replied "no... worse..." Before eventually getting to the trans thing. She then later told my dad. All in all, it was shakey, but I eventually started hrt at 19 in college after getting one of the guys I would talk to over the internet as a trap to buy them for me with bitcoin.
Now I am 25, I have still never girlmoded once, and have been boymoding for I guess 6 years, in addition to carrying this one thing as an obvious, inexorable, daily thought, fully articulated, and aware of since 12, so I guess 13 years.
Furthermore, I was never particularly feminine or masculine in early childhood. I remember thinking that the divisions between boys and girls were arbitrary since none of us chose to be either, and remembered feeling annoyed when in late elementary school I was told I had to leave the room during a period in which the teacher was to instruct all the girl students about how to be careful of boys, only to go out to the playground to get (what I considered) being bullied and treated roughly by the "other" boys.
I have had countless guys who were nominally straight/bi/into-"traps"-or-w/e develop long term crushes on me, from the age of 16 on usually multiple.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29373918
There are plenty of approaches to this problem. You can attempt to integrate an error function over a bunch of integrals over function spaces, you can try to minimize the norm of the difference between the approximation operator and the original, or you try to keep only the eigenvectors corresponding to the largest elements in the spectrum. For a bounded self adjoint compact operator like an integral operator of this kind, the spectrum is discrete and bounded. There are very simple ways to calculate the "largest" eigenvectors for operators of this kind. Why would I prefer to use a neural network model instead? I don't think it's simpler than my current method.

I think of it more as an application in physics but I can sympathize with disliking numerics. I would always favor an analytic problem over implementing some numerical trainwreck but sometimes it's just a necessary tool. In this case in the literature I just have not found good justifications for using spherical harmonics so analysis of possible alternative bases and their comparative efficiency seemed good to me.

I sympathize with hating type theory. I feel a lot of the category theory applied in Haskell and other languages is questionably necessary, even as someone who likes homological algebra. I feel that categorical language is strained and less natural in these settings than it is in algebraic topology or geometry.

Differential geometry is nice. I love geometry of 4-manifolds (classical stuff on Lefschetz fibrations and symplectic manifolds and I think recent stuff with trisections are interesting). Where are you in your formal education?

im gonna be biased, obviously, but I kindof think that's part of what makes bigen what it is.
There's all kinds of places on 4chan where no one gives a shit about anyone else and usually results in avatarfagging (which, if we're being honest with ourselves, is not qualitatively different from tripfagging) or an absent community where the same questions are asked over and over again. I mean, look at /a/. /a/ is one of the oldest boards on 4chan and it's rife with BOTH of those issues. And that's an entire fucking board, this is just one general.
There are places where there are enough posters or a varied enough subject matter to mitigate this problem, but im not sure if "liking cock and pussy" is one of them. I mean, look at gaygen.
I feel a lot of people, especially newfags from ~2016, have a romantic ideal of what 4chan is, was or is meant to be that is incongruous with reality. They point to the anonymity or trends of 4chan without understanding their roots or purpose. They wanna seem cool or just have a hatred of trips from most trips being annoying egotistical asshats.
I can't really say that's unwarranted or unjustified, but in my experience, the amount of egotistical trips on this general aren't much higher than the amount of egotistical people on 4chan in general. Really, most of the annoying or attention-whorey people who DO post on bigen tend to be non-trip avatarfags.
'Course, you could be against avatarfagging too, but that just brings us back to the previous point of bisexuality not being a diverse enough topic to justify a regular general. Not on a blue board, anyway.

I want to study everything about being a human so I can do it to the best of my ability while at the same time experiencing the world wholly self-realized. I would like humanity to come away from its crazed resource draining and constant armed conflict bordering on nuclear annihilation. I would also appreciate that each person's human rights be upheld per the Universal Declaration of human rights. And that means that in order to live you must not be enslaved. That those with disabilities are catered to so much as a society can afford to feed anybody. That I myself reach a maxim of self-awareness, finding the inner soul, the me who is. The seer of my vision and the listener of my thoughts. I want my consciousness to reach as far as its capacity. To fully self-realize and take my inner personality into this world and use my organs of action to serve others. This world is rife with pain and suffering for animal kind and humans alike. I want to transcend the pain of humans of lower dispositions, and by lower I mean selfish. It would be terrific if the massive west-coast volcano doesn't blow up while I'm around because that would mean massive suffering and loss to all my country. It's in a tough place still due to its internal issues. I would like to visit certain places only because action can take me there. If my mind wishes it, I could visit there. Almost anywhere. Now to be able to climb all sorts of rocky places, that is a gift to be grateful for. In fact, I would argue that wanting is of itself a selfish activity and could be done away with for my own personal heath.
>>29377618
The lesson being that it's difficult past your most basic desires. Elevate beyond, anon. What do you want, in totality? Don't stop before 450 words is the challenge.

Lunch Edition
previous: >>29311059

Goal of the thread: Treat yourself to something nice, be it a meal, a hot bath, or something else you'd enjoy doing.
Daily goals can be repeated. Remember to keep score, it can only go up!

>What is this thread for?
Getting better is hard, and sucks. A lot. It does not get easier doing it alone.
Share resources and experiences with combating depression, anxiety, personal issues, achieving or maintaining a healthy weight, etc.
>Why is this thread /lgbt/?
Struggles with mental and physical health are an indisputable part of /lgbt/ life, be it from dysphoria, social pressure, heartbreak, or just unfortunate lifestyle choices.
>Notes to consider:
Please be civil. Shame is your greatest enemy in fighting urges of self abuse (be it sh, drugs, or just self deprecation). Relapsing into bad and unhealthy habits is to be expected, the goal is to increase the average amount of time it takes between relapses. Any improvement is a victory no matter how small. Your worth and right to get better are non-negotiable. And most importantly:
WE ARE NOT THERAPISTS, WE DON'T REPLACE MEDICATION
>Note on advice
Generic advice won't necessarily help you in particular, but for those it does it is an essential foundation to build future progress on, not a miracle cure. Do not underestimate the effects subtle changes to your lifestyle can have. Try first, keep us posted on your progress, build from there.

We are *always* short on self help resources, so if anything was useful to you, let us know!
Since the OP is getting too long I moved all resources into their own post, see below!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
resources:
Exercise, diet, weight loss/gain: >>>/fit/17018018 (sticky)
Assorted self help resources (anxiety, depression, sleep issues, ED, and more) https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself
NIMH brochures on mental health topics (Depression, BPD, ADHD, etc): https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications
ED: https://www.eatingdisorderhope.com/treatment-for-eating-disorders

General advice from Anons: https://0x0.st/oh5x.txt

Get started with weight loss (courtesy of /fit/fat/):
>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with LoseIt, Cronometer or Waistline (Open Source)

A few short overview videos (need review by other anons):
Common Sources of Misery: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LO1mTELoj6o
Loneliness and its Health Effects: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n3Xv_g3g-mA
Making Friends: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9hJ_Rux9y0
Impact of Gratitude Exercises: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WPPPFqsECz0
Habituation 101: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=75d_29QWELk
A "game" on anxiety (and the author's experience fighting it):
https://ncase.me/anxiety/ and https://ncase.me/mental-health/

>>29342335
This one is measure theory, so it requires single+multi -variable calculus, linear algebra, differential equations, and real analysis.
TECHNICALLY it's standalone, but you need the "mathematical maturity" from at least real analysis imo, and for real analysis you need to be a little used to math (it's technically also stand alone).

I didn't do this proof by myself, we got it during lecture, and I expanded it to make it clear. Though, the induction proof (part 2) ) I wrote, since it was "left as an exercise" by professor.
But these proof build upon "properties" that are given, and then you have to manipulate some stuff to fullfil those properties criteria. So even though these sets are arbitrary, they're tested against properties while assumed to hold certain properties, and those properties can then give extra things to lead on (like mu(A intersection B) + mu(A intersection (B complement) = .mu(A) is part of the "outer-measure property", which only holds if A and B are disjoint, and so you can use that as an equivalence if all the criteria holds).

>>29362275


>although i don't know if you need to go as far as measure theory to make a video game.
I mean I kind of went off track, so now it's getting enough courses to become a HS math teacher as backup (and get 1.5 years of being free, since the education will be so easy).

>don't think that's possible. the best i could do is try to work from home then...not work.
Or work for like proper amount of time, then slowly but surely push it down to 4hrs but be fairly effective.
Then you can spend 4hrs a day on studying, and the rest you can relax on (or if you take an interest in maths you could do maths for fun).


>it's not just multivariable calc. it's a lot of subjects to try and build up to ML sadly.

I think you should do:
>discrete maths (dabbles a little into sets, relations, number line, induction proof, which are required)
>linear algebra
>single variable calculus
>multi variable calculus
>some mathematical statistics course (normal distributions, and linear regression and such)
>linear programming/optimization (continuous optimization is used in ML, for training and evaluating performance)

>real analysis (first dealings with proofs)
>topology (haven't done it, but required for differential geometry)

then maybe
>differential equations (after single variable, but I didn't really get anything out of it)
>abstract algebra (I haven't done it, but it's probably good, especially if you want to do something like algebraic topology)

Then you can tackle measure theory, functional analysis and differential geometry.
By technicality you can read real analysis before anything else, but it's gonna be very difficult to understand the concepts

>>29367509
It's difficult. I understand the feeling, I have been betrayed by a lover as well many moons ago. It depends on your general outlook what comes next. Some try to mend things, some prefer a fresh start. It is not my place to advertise one over the other, but I can tell you what you might need right now: time to rest and recover. For now, your feelings will be a mess, and it hurts. The best thing you can do right now is seek comfort. In friends, family, song, food (in moderation).. It won't help you process, and you will have to, but first you need to get over the initial shock, which can take a few days. When you feel you have gained a little distance to the event (it will still hurt though, sadly..) we can talk over the options you could take it and how you feel about them. Whatever you do though, don't look for reasons, don't try to rationalize if you can help it. Right now many people would only harm themselves with such thoughts.

>>29386105
>>29386188
Not quite, the idea is to slice R into countably infinitely many disjoint sets that are related to each other by translation. I'm not a mathematician and only gave it a brief read but I interpret it this way:
You want to slice (0,1) into countably many sets. We know a countable set that is dense in R, it's Q.
The equivalence classes Q+x (basically quotient group R mod Q of addition) divide R into uncountably many disjoint subsets of countable sets. If you allow me a sloppy analogue, we have just sliced (0,1) into uncountably many countably thin slices. We want the exact opposite, so we construct a vertical slice through these subsets, containing one element of each subset, obtaining a uncountably thick slices, but only countably many of them, and they are all identical up to translation.

A lot of those bad things wouldn't be so bad if you weren't already in such a bad way. It's obnoxious, but it's so much easier to focus on the bad shit and ignore anything that's even mildly pleasant. It feels fake to feel pleasure from dumb things that maybe used to make you happy. That's how I feel when I'm at my lowest at least.

When we're going to face bad shit no matter what, taking the effort to appreciate the good shit pays off with time. It's about the small pleasures. They distract you from bad thoughts. Those bad thoughts might seem important to hold on to, but you really need to assess if they're helpful or not. It's easy to get caught up thinking about your problems without being able to reach any solution. It's not productive. You need a distraction.

That's how I've trained myself to appreciate the little things and get out of my head. I'll watch a bug for a bit or play with my cat or read a book because otherwise I'll just scroll mindlessly on my phone thinking about my problems and being miserable.

>>29390470
here's the problem in question
>A coin that has probability of heads equal to p is tossed successively and independently until a head comes twice in a row or a tail comes twice in a row. Find the expected value of the number of tosses.

so my approach was to try and find a closed form solution since
P(X) = P(alternating sequence of size X-1, ending in H) * p + (same, ending in T)* (1-p)
but that was both something i couldn't write down cleanly and also not the solution given

the solution they give was this:
let q = 1-p (odds that it is tails)
then by total expectation theorem. E[X] = p*E[X|H1] + q*E[X|T1]
above because you split E[X] into the cases where the first toss was heads or tails

E[X|H1] = pE[X|H1 ^ H2] + qE[X|H1 ^ T2]
same logic. knowing that the first toss was tails, you toss the next one and you

E[X|H1^H2] = 2, since that represents the sequence HH at which we stop tossing the coin
E[X|H1^T2] = 1 + E[X|T1]. we know this because in the sequence HT, the first H does not change the outcome of the future. so this is the same as if we rolled tails and added 1

similar logic for T1 but reverse the roles of q and p, and we get the system
E[X|H1] = 2p + q (1 +E[X|T1])
E[X|T1] = 2q + p(1+E[X|H1])

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29391077
then you can solve this and get

E[X|H1] = (2q^2 + pq + q + 2p) / (1-pq)

another trick (which i missed) is that since q = 1-p, then q+p = 1 and you can simplify the above to
E[X|H1] = (2+q^2)/(1-pq)
and also get
E[X|T1] = (2+p^2)/(1-pq)

then you can plug those back into the original, partitioned equation for E[X] to get
E[X] = (p*(2+q^2) + q*(2+p^2)) / (1-pq)

which is further simplified to
E[X] = (2+pq)/(1-pq)

>>29391865
Not quite I'm afraid, or maybe I misunderstood what you were saying. i think this board supports unicode so the post should not be jumbled.
Okay, let's slow down. Equivalence classes [x] are a disjoint partition on any set. This particular one you can think of as a homomorphism ϕ(x) of addition where ker(ϕ)=Q.
So ϕ(a+b) = ϕ(a)+ϕ(b) = [a]+[b], with the intuitive property that [0]+[x]=[x], as any homomorphism should. For finite sets it becomes pretty obvious that every [x] has the same cardinality, the same is true in the finite case here as well though. Or more pragmatically, every equivalence class can be defined as [r] = {r+q : q ∈ Q} for any r∈R. The reason these sets are a disjoint partition is essentially because R is an additive group, but since that part is of no import since we take it for granted let's move on. Obviously, [r] is countable. However, that means that K={[r] : r∈R} is uncountable. We need a countable partition because our measures only care for countable unions. But if we have UNcountably many countable sets, we could reorder them to countably many UNcountable sets. That is what I meant by vertical slicing: Take one of the uncountably many elements from each [r], but only one, and form a new set of those, called E. That set, by definition, is uncountable, since it has one element from an uncountable number of sets (we can use [r] as an index). However, since we can enumerate the elements in each set [r]={x_{[r], 1},x_{[r], 2},..}, it means that we can form countably many E_n = {x_{[r], n} : [r]∈K} (I mean we literally just enumerated them) that are each uncountable (since K is) and together form once again all of R.
By restricting r to a finite interval we instead get a decomposition into disjoint unions of something that ought to be measurable (a finite interval). The actual proof just figures out a simple indexing that turns the E_n into translated copies of each other, completing the proof.

Long hair is going to hurt your hairline, bear that in mind. It gets pretty heavy, and assuming you brush it back like that woman that weight is constantly pulling back on your forehead.

My posture went from aristocratic snob too awful, and it's gotten a lot better doing self adjustments on my back.
Your back is most likely misaligned on top of the muscles being weak.

Working out and exercise will help a lot. Sitting with correct posture too.
But try laying on a hard floor, lift/roll your leg's up and lift them over your head past your head repeatedly.
This will crack your back and you will get immediate relief, and immediately better posture.
You can repeat this several times a day.

There are other ways to do this too, just look up self adjustments for your back.

No, this is a misreading of Marx. He did not hate German idealism as much as he had critiques of it while it was active as a movement but ultimately came to praise and value it especially later in life.

Marxism is only about amoral materialism if you read the bare text of the manifesto and das kapital, and even then it’s clear that while he’s explaining these phenomena, his explanations have no bearing on his real feelings.

His real feelings are made evident by his participation in the Paris Commune, i.e. by his actions. Certainly a lot of leftism is materialism, but notice that even in the manifesto you see the beginnings of ethics trickling in.

This is not to mention the fact that these works came off the back of the Conditions of the Working Class in England, which you must agree is at the very least a condemnation of those conditions.

Ethics is inherently material and materiality is inherently ethical. Trying to strip away one from the other dogmatically is at best unwise and at worse the biggest mistake, I’d argue, that western philosophers have made since the reformation: pretending philosophy is only about metaphysics and metaphysics bears no relation to ethics.

Unrestrained Capitalism definitely isn't perfect. the USA learned that the hard way, when the famous robber barons tried to get monopolies and acquire vertical chains of production. History is repeating itself now, as corporations keep getting larger.
Another issue is with some "public goods". Roads and mail are specifically enumerated as a responsibility of Congress in the US Constitution. Power and water fall under this category, but are heavily regulated. Similarly, only the batshit insane argue for a privatization of fire departments. In my opinion, railways could or SHOULD be nationalized, and handled more like roadway are.
For all the Soviet Union's flaws, their rail system was spectacular, and America's is shit - full of one-rail lines, accidents, and hold-ups because adding additional lines is a large investment that damages quarterly profits.

A corporate-stakeholder run society is a terrible mistake. Where a private business has a long-term strategy to retain its customers, and by extension its reputation and goodwill, stock investors do not care. Stakeholders will buy an asset, run it into the ground for short-term profits, and do not care if it crashes and burns, because they can easily sell their shares. Sadly, an enormous share of businesses use this model and you're seeing the country run into the ground by neo-robber barons.
The key is always a separation of powers, the state must check the businesses and so forth. The unholy alliance of state and big business is a shit show where your corporate overlord writes his own laws.

>>29385050
Merleau-Ponty suggests that great writers do not simply present new ideas or information, but they convey it in a newly compelling way. I think it is worth reading Marx himself, since the kind of approach his writing suggests is more valuable than the whole of his predictions or invented terminology.

His predictions are not specific enough to make high quality experiments of them: he does not propose interventions we can run in double blind trials. I am not familiar of any authors who do.

I think some are illuminating though: claims that people will seek religion as long as they are materially mistreated, or that we need autonomy in our work environments to be truly happy.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmacology_of_bicalutamide
>Bicalutamide more than blocks the effects of the increased testosterone levels that it induces in men, which is evidenced by its dose-dependent antiandrogenic effects and by the fact that monotherapy with the drug is about as effective as GnRH analogue therapy in the treatment of prostate cancer.[80][60] However, in contrast, the effects of the elevated estrogen levels remain unopposed by bicalutamide, and this is largely responsible for the feminizing side effects (e.g., gynecomastia) of the drug in men.[100]

>finasteride is very expensive in my country, so I'm considering DIY HRT antiandrogens.
I would've thought Bica would be more expensive than Fin, that's weird.
>Is bicalutamide going to make my hair stay on my head?
Possibly.
>sufficiently high relative concentrations of bicalutamide (1,000- to 10,000-fold excess) are able to completely prevent activation of the AR by androgens like DHT and testosterone and subsequent upregulation of the transcription of androgen-responsive genes and associated effects.
>At steady-state, relative to the normal adult male range for testosterone levels (300–1,000 ng/dL),[47] circulating concentrations of bicalutamide at 50 mg/day are roughly 600 to 2,500 times higher...
>is that going to make me grow boobs too?
This study was performed with 50mg Bicalutamide as a monotherapy treatment
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7502428/
>N=243
>Breast Pain: 117 (48%)
>Gynaecomastia : 78 (32%)
The Phase 3 trial results (150mg)
https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00657904
>N=3923 (bica group)
>Breast Pain: 2963 (73.7%)
>Gynaecomastia: 2766 (68.8%)
You can try to extrapolate the data from these two points in terms of chance for 25mg (or 50mg EOD, like you wanna do), but it's still gonna be a gamble

>>29356663
no, they don't increase blood clot risk even in high doses
>PEP produces minimal undesirable effects on coagulation factors and is thought to increase the risk of blood clots little or not at all.[33][34] This is in spite of the fact that estradiol levels can reach high concentrations of as much as 700 pg/mL with high-dose (320 mg/month) PEP therapy.[35] It is also in contrast to oral synthetic estrogens such as diethylstilbestrol and ethinylestradiol, which produce marked increases in coagulation factors and high rates of blood clots at the high doses used to achieve castrate levels of testosterone in prostate cancer.[33][34][6] The difference between the two types of therapies is due to the bioidentical and parenteral nature of PEP and its minimal influence on liver protein synthesis.[33][34][6] PEP might in fact reduce the risk of blood clots, due to decreases in levels of certain procoagulatory proteins.[33][34]

>>29348963
You can use the injections simulator to try and gauge a rough dose, but it's not indicative in any way. What might be a good dosage for one can be either too high or too low for another.
https://transfemscience.org/misc/injectable-e2-simulator/
6 mg/7 days gives me troughs of 302 pg/mL, which is actually almost on par with the sim, but a little less. I've heard stories of some people being several standard deviations off this curve though.
>>29349831
Bare minimum T, E2
SHBG, LH, FSH, Prolactin are useful to have. I'd argue these are potentially necessary. LH & FSH to check for gonadal suppression, SHBG to guesstimate free Estradiol. Prolactin is good to check if you're on Cypro or high dose E. Most blood testing utilities will sell these as a part of a package alongside T/E2.
Liver Function, Kidney Function, Thyroid, Full Blood Count, useful for additional safety if you're taking medication secondary to Estradiol i.e. non-GnRH based anti androgens.
The rest is issue-dependent. Some will argue DHT should be tested but serum concentrations are never representative of peripheral tissue concentration.

Your stack sounds good. I've not used Seri myself but I do use Redensyl as an adjunct treatment to Minoxidil, that might be something else to consider. Don't wanna throw too many products on though lol, becomes unmanageable.
>Minox (oral? topical? not sure yet)
Oral Minox is more efficacious than topical but start with topical, oral really isn't necessary for everyone and it's really not good for your health lol.
>Microneedling
Just don't needle too often, I'm doing 0.6mm every 3 weeks with 11-pin cartridges. Use a pen too, slow linear passes or stamping. Most studies are done w/1.5 but a recent one came out comparing 0.6mm vs 1.2mm and 0.6mm had better results. I think going too deep can damage the DPCs too much, especially in miniaturized hairs since they sit higher, nearer the epidermis rather than the dermis. Also go for mild arrhythmia and not bleeding errywhere. I'm sure you know all this based on what you wrote anyway tbf.
Oh and don't forget to manage your Prolactin. That shit kills hair. Don't want it too high.
>Should I also add Bica to this regimen?
Probably not necessary if your HPG axis is completely suppressed with E and you're using Dut. I'd pick between the two personally, Dut or Bica. Personally I like the idea of still having neurosteroids lol so I use Bica. But that's also because I'm on Prog.
Lmk if you have any questions, I should try and make /hlg/ again but with an actual wiki. Thinking of making a community wiki/site.

posts.com:
>>29360552
>nail the stack and make some gains then slowly minimize my usage of Minox.
Ya I'd just be worried about losing gains in whatever minxodil-dependent hair you have, in terms of density/thickness if you taper off, or entirely if you stop it.
>That IS interesting, I had no idea. I was following the conventional wisdom of 1.5mm every 2 weeks with a pen.
Yea, I mean it's only one study I suppose.
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32897622/
There's still no consensus on best protocol, but for myself re: depth, I go based off this pape:
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/cup.13467
>Moreover, the depth of the hair root in a miniaturized hair is 0.646 ± 0.140 mm. In terminal hairs, the depth of the hair root is 3.8 to 4.6 mm in Caucasians and 4.0 to 5.0 mm in Asians.
I've only just switched to 0.6mm from 1.2mm. I tried 1.5mm too but I was scared of damaging anything. I hadn't noticed any real significant regrowth in those slick areas, so I changed it up. For my slick bald areas, I now do 0.6mm. I might increase the depth for my thicker areas (in terms of hair density), especially because outer hair gets in the way of the needles a bit. Or generally just vary the depth every so often between 0.6-1.2. Will report back lol.
>Even with 1.5mm though, I've never been able to bleed.
I find that 0.6mm, if I use a stamping technique, does give pinprick bleeding. When I glide I don't find it happening as much. I think it was down to precision and consistency in terms of how close I got the device to my scalp.
>I'm clueless about the effects of prolactin and how to manage it, do you have any pointers about it?
Tbf I do need to look into Prolactin more regarding hair loss as per >>29360816. Prolactin plays a part in the development of the mammary alveoli (milk glands) and subsequent lactation. Estradiol regulates the release of Prolactin, the more E, the more Prolactin. Other drugs can cause rises in Prolactin too, like dopamine antagonists (some antipsychotics).

>>29364555
>I'm not sure whether or not it should mention serum, and it measures the total amount of testosterone
Yea they're the same, different terminology. When people talk about Serum T they're usually referring to Total Testosterone. Free Testosterone, on the other hand, is an estimate of biologically active T (i.e. how much T is actually being used by your tissues) that's not bound to proteins like SHBG or Albumin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29392852
For enanthate, 5mg/7days or 10mg/14 days is common. Shorter interval is preferred for smoother levels, but for convenience or if you're scared of needles the longer interval doesn't hurt. For valerate, you'd do 2mg/3 days or 5mg/7days, but I'd prefer enanthate if you can get it. Smoother curve and more convenience.

That's monotherapy. If he insists on prescribing you an AA you should ask for 50mg bica/day and either 2.2mg enanthate/week or 1.2mg valerate per three days. This should give you levels ~150pg/mL, a bit high for a cis woman but common for trans. Ask him to schedule you a female hormone test three months in, so you can be sure the monotherapy is eliminating your T or the AA+lower dose is giving you roughly 150pg/mL. You'll want to test for E1, E2, LH, and T.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29390757
1st and most important step, get your size measured by a professional. having a proper fit will make the whole experience of wearing one a lot more comfortable.

secondly, you don't need 7 bras. you can easily wear a bra 2-3 times before washing, even more if you don't sweat much and shower regularily (a stretch considering the site we're on), which leaves more than enough room to only need 2 or 3.

for what style to buy is up to you, generally t-shirt and/or any sort of wireless bra is going to be the most comfortable and least intrusive. quality bras that last are going to cost a pretty penny, easily at least 50usd a pop, and even then you're only supposed to wear them for 6-9 months before buying a new one (you can thank the women's clothing industry for that)

if you're very flat, A-cup or smaller, you *will* have trouble finding bras without some band extender shenanigans (which leaves them ill-fitting in other areas), my recommendation there is to go for bralettes, if you even think you need any sort of upper underwear at all

if you don't have any sort of specialty lingerie stores accessible to you, you can get reasonably high quality bras online from ThirdLove, they have a decent fitting tool and sell bras down to very small sizes with half-cup increments.
